titlestmt.titleproper: An Inventory of the Elbridge Durbrow papers, 1926-1996
titlestmt.author: Finding aid prepared by Rita Morin.

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using the Archivists' Toolkit 2012-01-12T16:35-0800
profiledesc.langusage: Finding aid is written in English

did.langmaterial: In English, French, Russian, and Polish
did.abstract: The collection documents the U.S. Foreign Service career and post-retirement of Elbridge Durbrow relating to the spread of communism, U.S. foreign policy and world politics following World War II, represented in the form of correspondence, clippings, interview transcripts, speeches and writings, press summaries, other printed material, and memorabilia. Consisting largely of Durbrow's writings, research materials, and correspondence, the collection reflects Durbrow's vast subject knowledge and expertise in foreign affairs.

accessrestrict.head: Access
accessrestrict.p: The Hoover Institution Archives only allows access to copies of audiovisual items. To listen to sound recordings or to view videos or films during your visit, please contact the Archives at least two working days before your arrival. We will then advise you of the accessibility of the material you wish to see or hear. Please note that not all audiovisual material is immediately accessible.

userestrict.head: Publication Rights
userestrict.p: For copyright status, please contact the Hoover Institution Archives.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: [Identification of item], Elbridge Durbrow papers,1938-1996, [Box number], Hoover Institution Archives.

acqinfo.head: Acquisition Information
acqinfo.p: Acquired by the Hoover Institution Archives in 1985.

accruals.head: Accruals
accruals.p: Materials may have been added to the collection since this finding aid was prepared. To determine if this has occurred, find the collection in Stanford University's online catalog at http://searchworks.stanford.edu/. Materials have been added to the collection if the number of boxes listed in the online catalog is larger than the number of boxes listed in this finding aid.

relatedmaterial.head: Related Materials
relatedmaterial.p: Elbridge Durbrow Oral History, Columbia Center for Oral History, Columbia University Libraries
Oral History Interviews, Harry S. Truman Library and Museum
Lyndon Baines Johnson Oral History Collection, Lyndon Baines Johnson Library and Museum

chronitem.event: Born, San Francisco, California
Bachelor of Arts, Philosophy, Yale University
Graduate studies at Stanford University and L'Académie de Droit International de la Haye; diploma in Sciences Politiques, École Libre des Sciences and Politiques
U.S. Vice-Consul, Warsaw, Poland and Bucharest, Romania
U.S. Vice-Consul, Moscow, U.S.S.R., The United States' first mission to the U.S.S.R.
U.S. Consul in Naples, Italy
Postgraduate work, University of Chicago
U.S. Consul, Rome, Italy, and Lisbon, Portugal
Member of the U.S. delegation at the Bretton Wood Conference
Chief of the Eastern European Division, State Department
U.S. Deputy Chief of Mission, Moscow, U.S.S.R.
U.S. Deputy for Foreign Affairs and instructor, National War College
Division of Foreign Service Personnel, U.S. State Department
U.S. Deputy Chief of Mission, Rome, Italy
U.S. Minister and Consul General, Singapore
U.S. Minister and Consul General, Singapore
Alternate permanent representative to the North Atlantic Treaty Organization Council in Paris, France
Advisor to the commander of the Air University at Maxwell Air Force Base, Alabama
Retired from the State Department
Director, Center for International Strategic Studies and the Freedom Studies
Chairman, American Foreign Policy Institute
President, Security and Intelligence Fund
Died, Walnut Creek, California

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content of Collection
scopecontent.p: The majority of the collection focuses on the materials used by Durbrow in the research for his writings, speeches, and lectures on foreign affairs before and after retirement. The main themes in his work relate to the spread of and adherence to communism throughout the world after World War II, and the United States' policies and relations with the Soviet Union. Excerpts from various books, articles and essays on the subjects of communism, the Soviet Union and the Cold War used by Durbrow in his research can also be found throughout the collection.

The papers include notes, outlines, drafts, and final versions of Durbrow's writings, speeches, and lectures. The bulk of the material dates from after Durbrow's retirement from the U.S. Foreign Service, when he became involved in foreign policy and national security think tanks, continuously researching, writing, and lecturing on foreign affairs.

Throughout the collection there are notes related to research topics, lectures, speeches, and writings, along with annotations on most clippings. In addition there are transcripts of radio and television interviews given by Durbrow; along with interviews for oral history projects at Columbia University, Lyndon Baines Johnson Oral History Collection and the Harry S. Truman Library.

Accompanying these materials is correspondence pertaining to Durbrow's writings, research, and personal matters. In particular, there is correspondence with prominent figures of the time: George Kennan, Clare Booth Luce, Walter Cronkite, William F. Buckley Jr., Ronald Reagan, and Spiro Agnew.
